thread.title: High School Football: Rebels face No. 1 Fayetteville today
thread.title_full: High School Football: Rebels face No. 1 Fayetteville today

title: High School Football: Rebels face No. 1 Fayetteville today
text:
High School Football: Rebels face No. 1 Fayetteville today High School Football: Rebels face No. 1 Fayetteville today BRIAN D. SANDERFORD • TIMES RECORD Southside’s Kevin White, right, breaks away from Bentonville’s Aaron Estrada during the second quarter on Friday, Sept. 25, 2015 in Bentonville. High School Football: Rebels face No. 1 Fayetteville today Buy Photo BRIAN D. SANDERFORD • TIMES RECORD Southside’s Evan Simpson catches a pass from Cooper Johnson in the end zone for a second quarter touchdown as Bentonville’s Aaron Estrada defends on Friday, Sept. 25, 2015 in Bentonville.

[strong]TODAYS TICKET[/strong]

[strong]Southside at Fayetteville[/strong]

[strong]TIME:[/strong] 7 p.m.

[strong]RECORDS:[/strong] Southside (2-2, 0-1); Fayetteville (4-0, 1-0)

[strong]RADIO[/strong]:

[strong]LAST WEEK:[/strong] Fayetteville defeated Northside, 45-19; Bentonville beat Southside 42-14

[strong]FEARLESSFRIDAY.COM RANKINGS:[/strong] Fayetteville is ranked No. 1 in Class 7A; Southside is No. 5 in Class 7A

[strong]LAST MEETING:[/strong] Fayetteville defeated Southside, 56-14, on Nov. 28, 2014

By Kevin TaylorTimes Record • ktaylor@swtimes.com Fayetteville football coach Darryl Patton has the best of all worlds: athletes, skill players, and a quarterback who’s putting up incredible numbers. And, he’s just a junior. Quarterback Taylor Powell leads the No. 1-ranked Purple Dogs today against the Southside Rebels. Powell has passed for 1,172 yards, 16 touchdowns and just two interceptions. “If there’s a quarterback in the country playing better I’d like to see him,” Patton said. “He’s playing well, and those around him are playing well.” “He’s one of the top quarterbacks in the state,” Southside coach Jeff Williams said. “He’s got a lot of weapons around him, and when he gets those guys out in space they can do damage.” Powell has completed 71 percent of his passes, with half going to three players — Barrett Banister (15 for 198); Terrance Rock (15-170) and; Tyson Morris (14-318). “We have tackled well in space, that’s a big key,” Williams said. “We have to rush the passer well. They’re big up front and they can run the ball really well.” Southside quarterback Cooper Johnson has already passed for 1,002 yards. He’s been intercepted just once. “The (Southside) quarterback is playing really well,” Patton said. “Defensively we’ve got our work cut out for us, because they do so many different things offensively. I’ve known Jeff Williams a long time, and one thing you know about him is his team’s are going to get after you.” Patton said the Purple Dogs appear to be pretty healthy. “We’re healthy and ready to go,” Patton said. “If we’re not, we’ll use the next man up approach.” The same can’t be said for the Rebels. Although running back Tanner Grandstaff returns today following an August knee injury, the Rebels won’t have the services of senior linebacker Andrew Clark. The team’s third leading tackler (26 unassisted stops and eight for negative yardage) said he tore his meniscus in the first quarter. He played the rest of the game, but was scheduled to have surgery today. He said he hopes to return for the Northside game. Today marks what is likely the final conference game ever between Southside and Fayetteville. The two schools have been playing since 1964. “Just mention the name Southside and you know about the history,” Patton said. Southside will be rid of the top two teams in the conference following today’s game. The Rebels will play four of their final five games in Fort Smith, with the lone exception an Oct. 16 date at Heritage. “”That’s part of it,” Williams said. “You have to play everybody some time. We have to play the No. 1 and No. 2 team back-to-back. but that’s part of the 7A-west. “It’s a good challenge for our kids, and they’re looking forward to it.”
